item.title: Trump’s Kennedy Center Shutdown Plan Jolts Workers and Performers
item.description: The administration’s announcement to shut the center for a major overhaul led to a swirl of confusion and anxiety among performers and patrons about its future.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney and Julia Jacobs
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The sudden announcement that the Kennedy Center will close for two years, starting in July, has created confusion among workers, performers and ticket holders.

item.title: Jewish Heirs Say Met Museum Pissarro Was Sold Under Nazi-Era Duress
item.description: The museum says a Jewish collector received a fair price for the work in 1941. The heirs say sales from that time are considered to have been forced and void under French law.
item.dc:creator: Tom Mashberg
item.media:credit: via The Metropolitan Museum of Art
item.media:description: “Haystacks, Morning, Éragny” by Camille Pissarro, which dates from 1899.

item.title: My 5 Favorite Places for Art in Los Angeles
item.description: Our critic Jason Farago shares what you shouldn’t miss in a city with as much culture off the silver screen as on it.
item.dc:creator: Jason Farago
item.category: Huntington Library, Art Collections and Botanical Gardens

item.title: At a Charged Time for Jewish Culture, Stand-ups Confront the Moment
item.description: Not so fast. A new special from Raanan Hershberg shows how charged times can make for funnier jokes involving anxiety over Israel, Gaza and antisemitism.
item.dc:creator: Jason Zinoman
item.media:description: Raanan Hershberg in his new special, “Morbidly Jewish.”

item.title: Sean Hayes Suffers Writer’s Block and More Horrors in ‘The Unknown’
item.description: In David Cale’s “The Unknown,” the actor plays 11 characters including a writer suffering the horrors of writer’s block and an unraveling mind.
item.dc:creator: Erik Piepenburg

item.title: At the U.S.-Mexico Border, a Children’s Opera Sings to the Moment
item.description: “Pancho Rabbit and the Coyote,” performed on both sides of the border, offers an allegory about migrants, immigration agents and President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney
item.media:credit: John Francis Peters for The New York Times
item.media:description: Victor Ryan Robertson, center, as Coyote, in Anthony Davis and Allan Havis’s new opera “Pancho Rabbit and the Coyote” at the Teatro de la Casa de la Cultura in Tijuana, Mexico.

item.title: From ‘Hamilton’ to Issa Rae to Philip Glass: Here’s a List of Kennedy Center Cancellations
item.description: More than two dozen musicians, dancers, theater companies and other creative groups have pulled out of performing at the Kennedy Center since President Trump returned to the White House.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: The composer Philip Glass in 2015.

item.title: Review: This is Your Grandparents’ ‘Muppet Show,’ Fortunately
item.description: Nobody put too much thought into reinventing the gonzo variety classic for its revival. That’s what makes it a delight.
item.dc:creator: James Poniewozik

item.title: At City Ballet, Alexei Ratmansky’s Morality Tale Is Wrapped in Farce
item.description: “The Naked King,” based on “The Emperor’s New Clothes,” debuts Thursday. “I’ve been dealing with what I’ve been experiencing in life and in the news,” Ratmansky said.
item.dc:creator: Marina Harss
item.media:description: Alexei Ratmansky: “I think that laughter is actually a strong weapon.”

item.title: 7 Great Grammy Winners You Didn’t Hear on TV
item.description: Standouts from the preshow ceremony including Turnstile, I’m With Her, Durand Bernarr and more.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz
item.media:credit: Kyle Myles for The New York Times
item.media:description: Turnstile

item.title: Cher’s Luther Vandross Grammys Gaffe Joins a Long List of Award Show Flubs
item.description: “I don’t do this part very well,” the singer said, just before she seemed to award a Grammy to Luther Vandross, who died in 2005. Plenty of celebrities have made similar goofs.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Cher onstage at the 68th annual Grammy Awards on Sunday in Los Angeles.

item.title: Stars Bring ‘ICE OUT’ Pins and Fiery Speeches to a Political Grammys
item.description: Bad Bunny, Billie Eilish and Kehlani made strong statements about immigration on Sunday, while the host Trevor Noah drew President Trump’s ire.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.media:description: “No one is illegal on stolen land,” Billie Eilish said while accepting a Grammy on Sunday.

item.title: Justin Bieber at the Grammys: A Stripped-Down, Perspective-Shifting Performance
item.description: The pop star stripped down his music and himself for a vulnerable but assured solo performance of “Yukon” on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica
item.media:credit: Kevin Winter/Getty Images for the Recording Academy
item.media:description: Justin Bieber onstage at the Grammy Awards in Los Angeles on Sunday night.

item.title: The Utah High School Drill Teams Who Dance With Intense Precision
item.description: Two traditions, military dance and a game resembling Simon Says, make drill team distinct in Utah.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Sherman and Cassidy Araiza
item.media:credit: Cassidy Araiza for The New York Times
item.media:description: Locked in: On the bus to the competition in Sandy, Utah, the Charelles listened to the music for their routines on repeat.

item.title: Michael Kosta Blasts the Super Bowl Halftime Alternative
item.description: “Man, that is a real who’s who of ‘Who?’” Kosta mused about Turning Point USA’s concert as opposed to the halftime show led by Bad Bunny.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)

item.title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix in February
item.description: A new series from the creator of “Derry Girls” and an inside look at the world of competitive ice dancing are among the highlights this month.
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray
item.media:description: From left, Caoilfhionn Dunne, Roisin Gallagher and Sinead Keenan in a scene from “How to Get to Heaven From Belfast.”

item.title: Tom Britt, Designer of Larger-Than-Life Interiors, Dies at 89
item.description: A master of the grand gesture, he was as theatrical as his rooms, which were inspired by French chateaus and Italian palazzos. As he put it, “Why be ordinary?”
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green

item.title: Chuck Negron, Hitmaking Singer With Three Dog Night, Dies at 83
item.description: His tenor anchored generational hits like “Joy to the World” and “One” by one of pop music’s commercial powerhouses of the early 1970s.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams and Ali Watkins
item.media:description: Three Dog Night in 1971. From left, Danny Hutton, Chuck Negron and Cory Wells. They were one of the entertainment world’s most bankable acts from 1969 to 1975, turning out 21 Billboard Top 40 singles, including 11 in the Top 10.

item.title: 10 Movies to Stream for Black History Month
item.description: Watch these selections that highlight the range and evolution of Black film.
item.dc:creator: Robert Daniels
item.media:description: Mbissine Therese Diop in “Black Girl.”

item.title: Before a Rape Trial, a Theater Piece Passes Its Own Judgment
item.description: A new work by the director Lorraine de Sagazan looks at a high-profile case that will soon be heard in a French court.
item.dc:creator: Laura Cappelle

item.title: Jon Stewart Can’t Believe Elon Musk’s Choice of Holiday Party Venue
item.description: “You’re asking if Jeff Epstein has got any parties planned on the island on Christmas Day?” Stewart asked on Monday’s “Daily Show.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)
Late Night With Seth Meyers Podcast (Radio Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)

item.title: Trump Says He’s Only Renovating the Kennedy Center
item.description: Even though President Trump held a movie premiere for his wife’s new film there last week, he said the state of the building was “actually sort of dangerous.”
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh, Julia Jacobs and Luke Broadwater
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The announcement raised questions about whether President Trump has the power to unilaterally shut down and renovate the Kennedy Center.

item.title: Woodie King Jr., a Driving Force in Black Theater, Dies at 88
item.description: His New Federal Theater in New York provided a rare stage for Black playwrights and emerging actors, among them Denzel Washington, Phylicia Rashad and Chadwick Boseman.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes
item.category: For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow Is Enuf (Play)
item.media:credit: Aaron Lee Fineman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Woodie King Jr. in 2004 in front of the New Federal Theater in the Henry Street Playhouse building on Manhattan’s Lower East Side.

item.title: John Forté, Who Forged a Hip-Hop Redemption Tale, Dies at 50
item.description: He seemed destined for a glittering career, working with the Fugees and solo, and then landed in prison. After his sentence was commuted, he clawed his way back.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.media:description: John Forté in 2010. His rise in the music industry was swift, but his fall came just as quickly, when he was convicted of acting as a middleman in a scheme to transport $1.4 million worth of liquid cocaine.

item.title: Billy Bass Nelson, Original Bassist for Funkadelic, Dies at 75
item.description: George Clinton, while working as a barber, recruited him. Mr. Nelson went on to name the group and, with his bandmates, to be inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.category: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum
item.media:description: Billy Bass Nelson, seated at far right, with other members of Funkadelic in 1971.

item.title: Kid Rock to Headline TPUSA Alternate Halftime Show
item.description: Turning Point USA, the advocacy group founded by Charlie Kirk, will present a streamed concert that will go up against Bad Bunny’s performance at the Super Bowl.
item.dc:creator: Marc Tracy
item.media:description: Kid Rock will play at the TPUSA halftime show presented by the conservative group as an alternative to Bad Bunny’s Super Bowl performance.

item.title: When the Clowns Went to Church
item.description: Every February, clowns pack into a London church to honor Joseph Grimaldi, a pioneering 19th-century clown. Hundreds of onlookers come for the merriment, too.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall and Sam Bush
item.media:credit: Sam Bush for The New York Times

item.title: What to Know About the Kennedy Center and Trump’s Campaign to Remake It
item.description: The center, which opened in 1971, is one of America’s top cultural institutions. President Trump says he plans to transform the center to create a “new and spectacular” entertainment complex.
item.dc:creator: Qasim Nauman
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A view of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in January.

item.title: Best and Worst Moments From the 2026 Grammys
item.description: Addison Rae tapped into 2000s pop energy, Justin Bieber stripped things down and Bad Bunny got choked up at the 68th annual awards.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles, Lindsay Zoladz and Joe Coscarelli
item.media:description: Sabrina Carpenter performing “Manchild” early in the ceremony.

item.title: Slumping in the West, the Art Trade Eyes the Gulf
item.description: The new Art Basel Qatar fair is a chance for dealers to make inroads with wealthy residents. It’s an alluring alternative to saturated markets elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: Scott Reyburn
item.category: Sheikha Al Mayassa bint Hamad bin Khalifa Al Thani
item.media:credit: Adriane de Souza for The New York Times
item.media:description: The inaugural edition of Art Basel Qatar will be held at the M7 center in Doha, Qatar.

item.title: Emil Sands’s Fascination With the Mystery of the Human Form
item.description: “I’ve spent my whole life looking at other people’s bodies,” says the painter Emil Sands. “I’m trying to work out why they’re different from mine.”
item.dc:creator: Rose Courteau

item.title: What’s With That Voice People Use When Reciting Poetry?
item.description: It’s been described as embarrassing, clichéd or “unhelpful singsong.” Many poets dislike it too, but it’s a style they’ve learned from each other.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Cowles

item.title: ‘Solo Mio’ Review: Wishful Thinking in Italy
item.description: After being left at the altar, Matt (Kevin James) finds himself alone in Rome. But don’t worry, he’ll quickly find an Italian woman to fall for him.
item.dc:creator: Calum Marsh

item.title: Trump Assails Grammys and Threatens to Sue Trevor Noah Over Epstein Joke
item.description: President Trump declared the awards ceremony “virtually unwatchable” and accused Mr. Noah of defamation over a joke he made that appeared to tie the president to Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:description: Trevor Noah onstage during the 68th Annual Grammy Awards in Los Angeles.

item.title: Popcast: Grammys Instant Reactions! Bad Bunny Owns the Night
item.description: Popcast breaks down the show’s major moments in a live reaction episode immediately following the ceremony.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica, Joe Coscarelli, Sophie Erickson, Kate LoPresti, Pat Gunther and Nick Pitman
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times: Photo: Charles Rex Arbogast/Associated Press

item.title: Super Bowl LX, Plus 6 Things on TV This Week
item.description: The Olympic Games in Milan and Cortina begin, and the Seattle Seahawks face the New England Patriots.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez
item.media:description: Bad Bunny is set to perform at the 2026 Super Bowl.

item.title: Bad Bunny Wins Grammy for Album of the Year With ‘Debí Tirar Más Fotos’
item.description: One week before his Super Bowl halftime set, the Puerto Rican superstar won album of the year, defeating Lady Gaga, Kendrick Lamar and others.
item.dc:creator: David Browne
item.media:description: Bad Bunny came into the 2026 Grammys with six nominations.

item.title: Cher returns to the Grammys stage.
item.media:description: Cher accepted the lifetime achievement award on Sunday, during the 68th Grammys ceremony on Sunday.

item.title: Kendrick Lamar Wins 2nd Record of the Year Grammy for ‘Luther’ With SZA
item.description: The rapper took the category last year with “Not Like Us.” This time, he shared the honor with SZA for their duet “Luther.”
item.dc:creator: Marc Hogan
item.media:description: Kendrick Lamar and SZA performed together on a stadium tour last year.

item.title: ‘A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms’ Season 1, Episode 3 Recap: Waking the Dragon
item.description: Dunk makes a powerful new enemy. Egg makes his true self known.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.category: A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms (TV Program)
item.media:description: Dunk has provoked the dragon, a.k.a., Prince Aerion (Finn Bennett), a capital B, capital G Bad Guy.

item.title: Billie Eilish Wins Song of the Year Grammy for ‘Wildflower,’ Her 3rd in the Category
item.description: “Wildflower” beat tracks by Bad Bunny, Lady Gaga and Doechii.
item.dc:creator: Hank Shteamer
item.media:description: Billie Eilish performed at the 2025 Grammys with her brother, Finneas. This year she was up for both record and song of the year with “Wildflower.”

item.title: Bad Bunny Says ‘ICE Out’ in Grammys Acceptance Speech
item.description: After winning the award for best música urbana album, the Puerto Rican superstar took aim at the Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi
item.media:description: Bad Bunny accepting the award for best música urbana album during the Grammy Awards on Sunday.

item.title: Justin Bieber breaks his public performance pause at the Grammys.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez
item.media:description: Justin Bieber performing during the 68th Annual Grammy Awards on Sunday.

item.title: Olivia Dean Caps a Rocket-Ship Year With a Best New Artist Grammy
item.description: The “Man I Need” singer defeated a fellow British vocalist, Lola Young, as well as Leon Thomas, Addison Rae and others.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Horn
item.media:description: Olivia Dean received her first Grammy nomination this year, for best new artist.

item.title: ‘KPop Demon Hunters’ is inspiring fans to learn Korean.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin
item.media:credit: Jenna Schoenefeld for The New York Times
item.media:description: Language institutes are recruiting teachers to accommodate what they say is a surge in demand.

item.title: With six nods, Leon Thomas is ready for a Grammy spotlight.
item.dc:creator: Niela Orr
item.media:credit: Myles Loftin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Leon Thomas’s six nominations this year include two in major categories, album of the year and best new artist.

item.title: Who might make history? Kendrick Lamar, Bad Bunny and Rosé.
item.media:description: Rosé could be part of a K-pop breakthrough at this year’s Grammys.

item.title: Kehlani, Justin Bieber and More Wear ‘ICE Out’ Pins and Support Immigrants at Grammys
item.description: Bad Bunny joined Gloria Estefan, Shaboozey, Kehlani and others in speaking up for communities that are being targeted by ICE across the United States.
item.dc:creator: Marc Tracy

item.title: Kendrick Lamar, ‘KPop Demon Hunters’ and Leon Thomas lead early Grammy wins.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.media:description: Leon Thomas accepted best R&B album for “Mutt” during the premiere ceremony on Sunday.

item.title: ‘Golden’ gives K-pop its first ever Grammy.
item.dc:creator: Caryn Ganz
item.media:description: From left: Audrey Nuna, Ejae and Rei Ami, the singing voices of Huntr/x from “KPop Demon Hunters.”

item.title: Meet the 8 nominees for best new artist.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz
item.media:credit: Damien Maloney for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olivia Dean is one of two British singer-songwriters up for best new artist.

item.title: 2026 Grammys Takeaways: Bad Bunny and Kendrick Lamar Take Top Awards
item.description: On a night marked by explicit political statements, Bad Bunny became the first Spanish-language artist to win the ceremony’s top prize, while Kendrick Lamar is now the winningest rapper in Grammy history.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.media:description: Bad Bunny won album of the year at the 68th annual Grammy Awards in Los Angeles on Sunday.

item.title: After nearly 40 years, Candi Staton returns to the Grammys.
item.dc:creator: Garth Cartwright
item.media:credit: Kendrick Brinson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Candi Staton’s journey through gospel, soul, disco and Americana has been plagued by setbacks and struggles, but she has always found the path forward.

item.title: How to watch the 68th annual Grammy Awards.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: The prime-time Grammys begin at 8 p.m. on Sunday night.

item.title: Who’s nominated, performing and hosting?
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Sabrina Carpenter is returning as a performer at the 2026 Grammys.

item.title: ‘Golden’ From ‘KPop Demon Hunters’ Wins, Giving K-Pop Its First Grammy
item.description: The breakout song from “KPop Demon Hunters” won best song written for visual media on Sunday, ending a drought for the powerhouse global genre.
item.dc:creator: Caryn Ganz
item.media:description: From left: Audrey Nuna, Ejae and Rei Ami, the singing voices of Huntr/x from “KPop Demon Hunters.”

item.title: Grammys 2026 Winners List: Bad Bunny, Kendrick Lamar, Olivia Dean and More
item.description: A complete rundown of the artists, albums, songs and videos that took home trophies at the 68th annual awards.
item.media:description: Kendrick Lamar accepted the Grammy for best rap album on Sunday night in Los Angeles.

item.title: X.J. Kennedy, a Poet of Wit Who Clung to Rhyme and Meter, Dies at 96
item.description: Spurning the free verse of many of his contemporaries, he held to an older tradition. He also wrote spirited poems for children.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Chace

item.title: On ‘S.N.L.,’ Tom Homan’s Advice to ICE: ‘Don’t Get Filmed’
item.description: The “Saturday Night Live” alum Pete Davidson plays the border czar who was tasked with reorienting ICE agents in Minneapolis, replacing their ousted commander.
item.dc:creator: Dave Itzkoff

item.title: Best Movies and Shows Streaming in February 2026
item.description: The docuseries “Soul Power” and “The Muppet Show” arrive, and “Dark Winds,” “Monarch: Legacy of Monsters,” “Scrubs” and “John Oliver” return.
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray
item.category: Last Week Tonight With John Oliver (TV Program)
